questions.text: The command terms 'describe', 'explain', and 'discuss' all require the same type of response.
questions.explanation: Each command term requires a different response type. 'Describe' requires stating features. 'Explain' requires giving reasons why. 'Discuss' requires presenting multiple perspectives. Know the difference.
questions.studyTip: Describe = what. Explain = why. Discuss = multiple sides.

questions.text: Understanding command terms helps you structure responses that directly address what assessors expect.
questions.explanation: Many students lose marks by explaining when asked to describe, or describing when asked to discuss. The command term tells you exactly what format your answer needs.
questions.studyTip: Circle the command term. Let it guide your response structure.

questions.text: Rewriting the question in your answer booklet shows you understand what's being asked.
questions.explanation: Rewriting questions wastes valuable time and space. Assessors already know the question—they want your answer. Start answering immediately.
questions.studyTip: Don't rewrite questions. Use that time for better answers.

questions.text: Going straight to your answer without rewriting the question maximises your available response space.
questions.explanation: Answer booklet space is limited. Every line spent rewriting is a line not spent demonstrating your knowledge. Examiners specifically noted this wastes time.
questions.studyTip: First word of your answer should be your answer, not the question.

questions.text: If your answer is correct, assessors will work hard to read illegible handwriting.
questions.explanation: Assessors mark many papers quickly. If they can't read your response easily, you may lose marks even if your content is correct. Legibility is your responsibility.
questions.studyTip: If you can't read it quickly, neither can the assessor.

questions.text: Clear, legible handwriting ensures assessors can accurately evaluate your responses.
questions.explanation: Writing legibility was explicitly noted as an area for improvement. Take time to write clearly—a readable average answer scores better than an unreadable excellent one.
questions.studyTip: Slow down if your writing becomes messy. Clarity over speed.

questions.text: General knowledge about design is enough—you don't need to reference the specific case study material.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses refer directly to the information provided in the exam. Generic answers that ignore the stimulus material score lower than specific, contextualised responses.
questions.studyTip: Use names, properties, and details from the case study.

questions.text: Referring to specific details from the stimulus material demonstrates you can apply knowledge to context.
questions.explanation: When discussing mycelium bricks, reference their actual properties: biodegradable, moisture-resistant, insulating. Don't just write generally about 'sustainable materials'.
questions.studyTip: Quote the stimulus. Use its specific details.

questions.text: If you don't know an answer completely, it's better to leave the question blank.
questions.explanation: Attempting all questions was noted as a strength. Partial answers can earn partial marks. A blank answer guarantees zero marks.
questions.studyTip: Write something relevant. Some marks beat no marks.

questions.text: Attempting every question gives you the best chance of maximising your total marks.
questions.explanation: Even incomplete answers can demonstrate partial understanding. Assessors award marks for what you know, not what you don't. Never leave a question blank.
questions.studyTip: Every question attempted is another chance for marks.

questions.text: Naming a test like 'durability test' is sufficient when asked to describe an experiment.
questions.explanation: Naming the test isn't describing it. You must explain HOW the test works: what equipment, what procedure, what measurements. 'Durability test' alone scores poorly.
questions.studyTip: Describe = equipment + procedure + what you measure

questions.text: Describing an experiment requires explaining the procedure, equipment, and how results are measured.
questions.explanation: High-scoring response: 'Weights are placed on the material progressively until it breaks. The maximum weight held indicates durability.' This describes what actually happens.
questions.studyTip: Walk through the test step by step.

questions.text: Describing test results is the same as explaining how they justify a product concept.
questions.explanation: Results and justification are different. Results tell you what happened. Justification explains how those results support choosing one concept over another. You need both.
questions.studyTip: Results = what you found. Justification = what it means for your choice.

questions.text: Experiment findings justify a product concept by showing which design best meets end-user needs.
questions.explanation: Connect the dots: 'Testing showed Material A withstood 50kg while Material B failed at 30kg. This justifies choosing Material A for a product requiring durability.'
questions.studyTip: Test result → comparison → conclusion about best concept

questions.text: When asked to draw two visualisations of a product concept, drawing two different products is acceptable.
questions.explanation: Two visualisations means two views or configurations of the SAME product concept—like showing a sofa-bed as a sofa AND as a bed. Not two completely different products.
questions.studyTip: Same product, different views or functions.

questions.text: Multiple visualisations of one product concept show different aspects or configurations of the same design.
questions.explanation: Show your adjustable table at low height (coffee table) and high height (dining table). Same product, multiple functions visualised. This demonstrates the multi-functionality.
questions.studyTip: One concept, multiple states = correct approach

questions.text: Annotations on design drawings should simply label the parts of the product.
questions.explanation: Annotations should connect to end-user needs and design requirements, not just name parts. 'Foldable legs' is labelling. 'Foldable legs reduce storage space by 60%' addresses the end-user need.
questions.studyTip: Annotate WHY features matter, not just WHAT they are.

questions.text: Effective annotations explain how design features address specific end-user needs or concerns.
questions.explanation: Link each annotation to the brief: 'Compact when folded (space-saving)', 'Converts to bed (multi-functional)'. Show you understand the connection between feature and need.
questions.studyTip: Every annotation should reference an end-user need.

questions.text: The circular economy is the same as recycling—both involve reusing materials.
questions.explanation: Circular economy is broader. It has two cycles: technical (recycling metals, plastics) and biological (organic materials returning to earth). It's about keeping materials in use as long as possible, not just recycling.
questions.studyTip: Circular economy: technical cycle + biological cycle

questions.text: The circular economy includes technical cycles (recycling materials) and biological cycles (returning organics to earth).
questions.explanation: Technical: plastics and metals recycled into new products. Biological: cotton, mycelium, food waste decomposing and enriching soil. Both keep materials in productive use.
questions.studyTip: Technical = recycle. Biological = biodegrade and regenerate.

questions.text: Research and development (R&D) and market research are essentially the same thing.
questions.explanation: They're different. R&D is scientific and technical—discovering new materials, processes, and properties. Market research investigates consumer needs and market opportunities. Don't confuse them.
questions.studyTip: R&D = science/technical. Market research = consumer/business.

questions.text: Research and development involves scientific and technical work to discover new materials and processes.
questions.explanation: R&D explores material properties (weight, stretch, durability), develops new manufacturing processes, and tests innovations. This is distinct from surveying consumers about preferences.
questions.studyTip: R&D asks: what can this material do? Market research asks: what do customers want?

questions.text: Flexible and responsive manufacturing is the same as lean manufacturing.
questions.explanation: They're related but different. Lean focuses on eliminating waste. Flexible/responsive manufacturing focuses on adapting quickly to changes—adjusting batch sizes, incorporating design changes, responding to demand.
questions.studyTip: Lean = reduce waste. Flexible = adapt to change.

questions.text: Flexible and responsive manufacturing allows quick adaptation to design changes and demand fluctuations.
questions.explanation: Small batch production with short turnaround allows changes between batches. Multiple machines can scale output. CAD modifications implement immediately. This is flexibility and responsiveness.
questions.studyTip: Can you change quickly? That's flexible manufacturing.

questions.text: Primary and secondary research both involve finding information from existing sources.
questions.explanation: Primary research is original—you conduct experiments, surveys, or tests yourself. Secondary research uses existing sources—reports, studies, published data. The distinction is who gathered the information.
questions.studyTip: Primary = you do it. Secondary = someone else did it.

questions.text: Primary research is conducted by the designer; secondary research uses existing information from other sources.
questions.explanation: Primary: testing moisture resistance yourself, surveying end users directly. Secondary: reading published studies about mycelium properties, reviewing existing market data.
questions.studyTip: Did you gather it yourself? Primary. Did you find it? Secondary.

questions.text: The main purpose of prototyping is to create a finished product ready for sale.
questions.explanation: Prototyping is for testing, not selling. It identifies faults before mass production, gathers feedback, and validates that the design meets end-user needs. It's a development tool.
questions.studyTip: Prototype = test and improve, not sell.

questions.text: Prototyping helps identify faults, gather feedback, and validate designs before mass production.
questions.explanation: Prototypes reveal problems early when they're cheap to fix. They let you test with real users, identify the most viable concept, and justify your final design choice with evidence.
questions.studyTip: Find problems early, fix them cheaply.

questions.text: General terms like 'strong' and 'good quality' adequately describe material properties.
questions.explanation: Examiners noted students need to know specific material names, characteristics, and properties. 'Durable', 'moisture-resistant', 'biodegradable', 'insulating' are specific. 'Good' is not.
questions.studyTip: Use precise property terms: durable, tensile, thermal, etc.

questions.text: Material properties should be described using specific terms like durability, thermal conductivity, or tensile strength.
questions.explanation: Learn the vocabulary: durability, flexibility, thermal properties, moisture resistance, weight-to-strength ratio. These precise terms demonstrate technical understanding.
questions.studyTip: Build a vocabulary of specific material property terms.

questions.text: Critiquing a design means explaining why it's good.
questions.explanation: Critique requires analysing BOTH strengths AND weaknesses. Just listing positives isn't critiquing—it's promoting. High-scoring responses offer balanced, thoughtful examination.
questions.studyTip: Critique = strengths + weaknesses + balanced judgment

questions.text: A critique analyses and assesses both strengths and weaknesses, offering balanced examination.
questions.explanation: For triple bottom line: 'Economically, mycelium is cheaper than traditional materials (strength), but scaling production may be costly (weakness).' Cover both sides.
questions.studyTip: Every critique needs positives AND negatives.

questions.text: When asked about impacts on consumers, discussing impacts on manufacturers is equally valid.
questions.explanation: If the question asks about consumers, answer about consumers. Students lost marks discussing manufacturer impacts when asked about consumer impacts. Read carefully.
questions.studyTip: Consumer question = consumer answer. Read who it's about.

questions.text: Responses must address the specific stakeholder mentioned in the question.
questions.explanation: Consumer impacts: cost savings, safety risks, convenience. Manufacturer impacts: profit margins, production efficiency. These are different. Answer what's asked.
questions.studyTip: Underline the stakeholder in the question. Stay focused on them.

concepts.title: Triple bottom line has three parts

questions.text: When asked about economic and social sustainability, discussing environmental sustainability also earns marks.
questions.explanation: If the question specifies economic and social, environmental content won't be marked. Students weren't penalised for including it, but it didn't earn marks either. Focus on what's asked.
questions.studyTip: Asked for two dimensions? Answer those two, not all three.

questions.text: When asked about specific sustainability dimensions, focus your answer on those dimensions only.
questions.explanation: Economic: costs, profits, jobs. Social: community wellbeing, working conditions, safety. Environmental: emissions, waste, biodiversity. Know which is which.
questions.studyTip: Economic = money. Social = people. Environmental = planet.

questions.text: Ethical considerations in gathering research are the same as ethical considerations about product use.
questions.explanation: Research ethics: privacy, informed consent, data protection. Product ethics: sustainability, safety, fair labour. The question specifies research ethics—don't discuss product ethics.
questions.studyTip: Research ethics: consent, privacy, transparency.

questions.text: Research ethics include privacy protection, informed consent, and clear explanation of study purpose.
questions.explanation: When gathering data from participants: keep personal information private, explain the study clearly so participants know what they're agreeing to, allow withdrawal.
questions.studyTip: Research = how you gather. Product = how you make/use.

questions.text: Identifying a method like 'production schedule' is enough to earn full marks.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses identify without describing. You must explain what the method involves: a production schedule 'plans tasks, dates, materials, and processes to produce quality products efficiently.'
questions.studyTip: Identify = name it. Describe = explain how it works.

questions.text: Full marks require both identifying a method and describing how it works.
questions.explanation: Pattern: Name it, then explain it. 'Lean manufacturing (identify) coordinates just-in-time delivery so resources arrive when needed and products ship immediately (describe).'
questions.studyTip: Name + explain = full marks. Name only = partial marks.

questions.text: Naming creative and critical thinking techniques is enough without connecting them to the design process.
questions.explanation: You must connect techniques to the specific design context. How would mind mapping help develop the brick design? How would reviewing market trends inform the brick's features?
questions.studyTip: Technique + how it applies to this design = full marks

questions.text: Thinking techniques must be connected to the specific product development being discussed.
questions.explanation: Creative: 'Mind mapping to explore how mycelium could be shaped and combined with other materials.' Critical: 'Reviewing brick market trends to identify unmet needs.' Context matters.
questions.studyTip: Don't just define techniques—apply them to the case study.

questions.text: Creative and critical thinking techniques are only used in the second diamond of the Double Diamond process.
questions.explanation: Both diamonds use both types of thinking. First diamond: discover and define the problem. Second diamond: develop and deliver solutions. Creative and critical thinking apply throughout.
questions.studyTip: Both thinking types in both diamonds.

questions.text: The Double Diamond process uses creative and critical thinking in both the problem and solution phases.
questions.explanation: First diamond discovers problems (creative exploration) and defines them (critical analysis). Second diamond develops solutions (creative generation) and delivers them (critical evaluation).
questions.studyTip: Diamond 1: problem space. Diamond 2: solution space.

questions.text: A good end-user profile includes detailed personal information like names and birthdays.
questions.explanation: Personal details aren't necessary. What matters is context: who they are, what they need, why they'd use the product. 'Builders seeking eco-friendly alternatives to traditional materials' is sufficient.
questions.studyTip: Profile = role + needs + context, not fictional biography.

questions.text: An effective end-user profile identifies who the user is and the context of their needs.
questions.explanation: Focus on relevant characteristics: profession, requirements, constraints, goals. 'Apartment dwellers needing space-saving, multi-functional furniture' tells you what the design must achieve.
questions.studyTip: What do they need? Why? That's your profile.

questions.text: Evaluating a product means developing new criteria to judge it.
questions.explanation: When asked to evaluate using constraints you've identified, use THOSE constraints—don't invent new criteria. Lower-scoring responses created new evaluation criteria instead of applying stated constraints.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate against the constraints you already identified.

questions.text: Evaluation uses previously identified constraints to assess how well a product meets requirements.
questions.explanation: If your constraints were 'lightweight' and 'eco-friendly', evaluate by asking: Is it lightweight? (Yes, mycelium is lighter than clay.) Is it eco-friendly? (Yes, biodegradable.)
questions.studyTip: Constraint 1: does it meet it? Constraint 2: does it meet it?

questions.text: Production management is only about making products faster.
questions.explanation: It's about quality AND efficiency. Methods include production schedules, lean manufacturing, and emerging technologies. The goal is quality products produced efficiently—speed alone isn't enough.
questions.studyTip: Quality + efficiency, not just speed.

questions.text: Production management methods ensure quality products are produced efficiently through planning and coordination.
questions.explanation: Production schedule: plans tasks, dates, materials. Lean manufacturing: reduces waste, just-in-time delivery. Both aim for quality output with efficient resource use.
questions.studyTip: Plan + coordinate + minimise waste = effective production.

questions.text: Explaining how you'd use market information is the same as describing methods to gather it.
questions.explanation: When asked to DESCRIBE a method of investigating, explain HOW you gather information (questionnaires, surveys, analysis), not what you'd do WITH the information once gathered.
questions.studyTip: Describe method = how you collect. Don't skip to how you use.

questions.text: Describing investigation methods means explaining how data is gathered, such as through surveys or data analysis.
questions.explanation: Methods: 'Creating and distributing online questionnaires to the target population, then analysing responses to identify trends like increasing apartment occupancy.'
questions.studyTip: Method = the tool and process for gathering information.

questions.text: Research and development contributes to innovation by testing existing products for quality.
questions.explanation: Quality testing is important but isn't R&D's innovation contribution. R&D discovers NEW materials, processes, and properties—exploring unknown possibilities like polyamide 11's stretch and durability.
questions.studyTip: R&D discovers new possibilities. Testing checks existing ones.

questions.text: R&D contributes to innovation by exploring new materials and processes to enable novel design solutions.
questions.explanation: R&D on plant-based polyamide explores its properties, enabling designers to reimagine products like helmets. Without R&D discovering what's possible, innovation can't happen.
questions.studyTip: R&D = exploring the unknown to enable the new.

questions.text: Entrepreneurial activity only involves starting businesses to make profit.
questions.explanation: Entrepreneurship includes taking risks, creating innovative concepts, and seeking support from users and investors. Information campaigns can encourage designers to explore new materials and take creative risks.
questions.studyTip: Entrepreneurship = risk-taking + innovation + seeking opportunity.

questions.text: Information campaigns can encourage entrepreneurial activity by highlighting opportunities in new materials and processes.
questions.explanation: Learning about mycelium's benefits might inspire designers to take risks manufacturing with it, create unique concepts, and seek investor support. Awareness enables entrepreneurship.
questions.studyTip: Information → awareness → risk-taking → innovation

questions.text: Technology impacts on consumers and producers are essentially the same.
questions.explanation: They differ significantly. Consumer: ease of use, data privacy, satisfaction. Producer: production efficiency, data utilisation, scalability. Critique both perspectives separately when asked.
questions.studyTip: Consumer = using it. Producer = making it.

questions.text: Critiquing technology impact requires addressing both consumer experience and producer operations separately.
questions.explanation: Consumer: 'App makes ordering easier but lacks human contact.' Producer: 'App data streamlines production but requires clear user input.' Different stakeholders, different impacts.
questions.studyTip: Same technology, different stakeholders = different analysis.
